> @jleveque , you mention there were some issues on this pr [Azure/sonic-platform-daemons@14e586d](https://github.com/Azure/sonic-platform-daemons/commit/14e586d) ?

Yes, but Azure/sonic-platform-daemons@f6e5e59 resolves those issues. The check builds are passing, so the fix seems to work well.

>         argument = '-k Mellanox-SN2700 --preset l2 -p ' + self.t0_port_config

Could you add another test case for Mellanox-SN3800-D112C8 in the same way? #WontFix

---
Refers to: src/sonic-config-engine/tests/test_j2files.py:99 in dd1f4d9. [](commit_id = dd1f4d96b213668c166d05a8ae3e1652dd0cb4f2, deletion_comment = False)

> > ```
> >     argument = '-k Mellanox-SN2700 --preset l2 -p ' + self.t0_port_config
> > ```
> 
> Could you add another test case for Mellanox-SN3800-D112C8 in the same way?
> 
> Refers to: src/sonic-config-engine/tests/test_j2files.py:99 in [dd1f4d9](https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/commit/dd1f4d96b213668c166d05a8ae3e1652dd0cb4f2). [](commit_id = [dd1f4d9](https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/commit/dd1f4d96b213668c166d05a8ae3e1652dd0cb4f2), deletion_comment = False)

I think I understand your point: different device types have different sources of port configuration data, and it would be better to capture the difference. However, in this particular test, the data source is explicitly specified (tests/t0-sample-port-config.ini). So only changing the device type cannot test out the sources of port configuration data, and in this test setup, it does not seem the source of port configuration data could follow the `-k <device>` option. In using the command in SONiC, the `-k <device>` option should specify the data, and rendering the template should not be dependent on what kind of device it is. If you think the test case is indeed necessary, I think I need to copy the port config ini file for the device here and write another ground-truth json file for it. Let me know what you think.
@shi-su , can you check why warm reboot test failed? is it false alarm or real failure?

> @shi-su , can you check why warm reboot test failed? is it false alarm or real failure?

I tried to test with the image on my end and it passed the test. So possibly it is a false alarm. I will try to retest here. In the meantime, I will try if I could reproduce the failure and monitor if it happens anywhere else.

This may be suited for a future PR, but now that we are using FRR instead of quagga, the path `/var/log/quagga/` is a bit misleading. Maybe we should consider `/var/log/frr/` or a more generic `/var/log/bgp/`.
@yxieca - would you like to file an issue? Thanks.

@yxieca There is a dependency on this FRR log file for the functionality of bgpmon that is running inside the BGP docker.
If any changes made to either remove this log file or renamed it or moved to somewhere else, the code indie bgpmon will also need to be changed so that is can still take advantage of knowing there are FRR activities by monitoring this file's timestamp in order to avoid unnecessary polling neighbor info from BGP...
Closing this PR due to bgpmon issue Gen-Hwa identified. Putting back the original change in #5966
i am confused on which approach we are taking now?

> i am confused on which approach we are taking now?

According to Gen-Hwa/Judy/Arvind, we are taking this approach because bgpmon can work without tapping into the log. Judy will make a follow up change to make sure multi-ASIC frr logs are captured and put into /var/log/quagga/bgpd.log with name space tag.

@qiluo-msft: Check builds are failing because mock swsscommon calls appear to be unimplemented. Have you seen this before?

I guess it is related to this part of dynamic behavior in test
```
try:
    from swsscommon import swsscommon
except ImportError as e:
    from tests import mock_swsscommon as swsscommon
```

It is not recommended practice. It assumes swsscommon is missing in unit test environment.

Good find! Thanks, Qi! I believe this was recently exposed because sonic-utilities recently started depending on swsscommon, which caused to to get installed in the build environment earlier than previously.

I'd suggest use encoding='utf-8'. This will convert the results to strings.
universal-newlines sounds like to support Windows and linux newlines

> I'd suggest use encoding='utf-8'. This will convert the results to strings.
> universal-newlines sounds like to support Windows and linux newlines

I looked into this, and it seems like `universal_newlines` is the proper solution:

- https://stackoverflow.com/questions/38162400/python3-popen-do-i-have-to-use-encode-every-time

In fact, it appears as though as of Python 3.7, they have added an new `text` alias for `universal_newlines` because the parameter was unfortunately named and confusing:

> Changed in version 3.7: Added the text parameter, as a more understandable alias of universal_newlines

I can change these to read `text=True` to take advantage of the new alias. Would you prefer that?

- https://python.readthedocs.io/en/latest/library/subprocess.html?highlight=universal_newlines

Edit: I have replaced all instances of `universal_newlines=True` with the new alias, `text=True`

Edit 2: Unfortunately, I had to revert back to `universal_newlines=True` because sonic-py-common needs to continue supporting both Python 2 and 3, and `universal_newlines=True` is available in Python 2, whereas `text=True` was introduced in Python 3.4. Thus, we have to stick with `universal_newlines=True` until we completely remove support for Python 2, then we can change them to `text=True`.

The switch MAC address comes from the syseeprom on the ixs7215 just like most other boxes with syseeproms.  The previous et6448m marvell/delta product did not have a syseeprom so on that box the mac was placed into profile.ini early in boot up from uboot/ONIE env via a “virtual” syseeprom.   The mac address “00:50:43:ee:ee:ee “ is a “dummy” and is replaced with the boxes actual mac address at boot up.  I plan to push a change to sonic-py-common/sonic_py_common/device_info.py  early this week modifying the “get_system_mac” routine for ['asic_type'] == 'marvell'  to clean up the method there.  For marvell sai consistency the ixs7215 replaces the dummy mac with the actual syseeprom mac into profile.ini at boot via the nokia-7215init.service calling marvell-armhf/sonic-platform-nokia/7215/scripts/nokia-7215init.sh   The marvell sai uses the mac in that file.

## from this
```python
l1_oneHundredGbe = OneHundredGbe(link_training=True,

common_l1_config = Layer1(name='common L1 config',

comments.body: @jleveque can you please review this PR?
@madhanmellanox: Can you please explain the need for this? Why can't we continue relying on the rule prop keys to be all caps? And why the need for this now? What changed?

@jleveque because we check for SRC_IPV6 / DST_IPV6 / TCP_FLAGs in caclmgrd code, the checks are becoming case sensitive and when we configure using lower case letters, the ACL rule is not working. For example, in my ACL rule if I have SRC_IPv6 instead of SRC_IPV6, the rule in ip6tables is not right. This is because of cases sensitive checks we make in the code. It is a Day-1 issue. It is not new.

@madhanmellanox: The acl-loader application configures these to be all-caps before inserting them into config DB. The only way I can see this being a problem is if you're adding them manually, in which case, why not add them as all caps?

I'm not opposed to this change, but I'm just not convinced that it's necessary.
Yes, this is our QA defect and they individually configure the ACLs manually. In any case it should not fail.

I see. Technically, this is human error, as it doesn't follow the spec we had defined, where these keys should always be uppercase in config DB. I feel like we should firm up a spec here, but as this change seems safe, I think we can go ahead with it.

However, please note that I have an open PR to migrate caclmgrd to Python 3 and move it to a new package in the master branch: https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/pull/5739. That PR should be merging soon, in which case, this PR will have conflicts, and will need to be rebased, but then it will not be cherry-pickable to 201911, so a separate PR would be needed.

```
Also you need to install sonic-py-common and swsssdk for that
```
git clone https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage.git
cd sonic-buildimage/src/sonic-py-common
sudo python setup.py install
git clone https://github.com/Azure/sonic-py-swsssdk.git

```

```
pyang -Vf tree -p /usr/local/share/yang/modules/ietf /usr/local/yang-models/*.yang

It is not a critical content in the package, so we can safely remove it.
